Then those who are left alive will accept the punishment for their sins. They will learn that they were punished because they ·hated [disdained] my ·laws [regulations] and ·refused to obey [abhorred] my ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements].

44.verse: But even though this is true, I will not ·turn away from [disdain] them when they are in the land of their enemies. I will not ·hate [abhor] them so much that I completely destroy them and break my ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with them, because I am the LORD their God.

45.verse: For their good I will remember the ·agreement with their ancestors [former covenant/treaty], whom I brought out of the land of Egypt [the covenant with Moses; Ex. 19–24] so I could become their God; the other nations saw these things. I am the LORD.’”

46.verse: These are the ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements], ·rules [regulations], and ·teachings [laws; instructions] the LORD made between himself and the Israelites through Moses at Mount Sinai.

1.verse: Promises Are Important - The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: “Speak to the ·people [sons; children] of Israel and tell them: ‘If someone makes a ·special promise [vow] ·to give a person as a servant to the LORD by paying a price that is the same value as that person [concerning an equivalent for a person; a person, such as a child or a slave, could be given for God’s service, or money paid instead to fulfill the vow],

3.verse: the ·price [equivalent] for a man twenty to sixty years old is about ·one and one-fourth pounds [fifty shekels] of silver. (You must use the measure as set by the ·Holy Place [sanctuary].)

4.verse: The ·price [equivalent] for a woman twenty to sixty years old is about ·twelve ounces [thirty shekels] of silver.

5.verse: The ·price [equivalent] for a man five to twenty years old is about ·eight ounces [twenty shekels] of silver; for a woman it is about ·four ounces [ten shekels] of silver.

6.verse: The ·price [equivalent] for a baby boy one month to five years old is about ·two ounces [five shekels] of silver; for a baby girl the price is about ·one and one-half ounces [three shekels] of silver.

7.verse: The ·price [equivalent] for a man sixty years old or older is about ·six ounces [fifteen shekels] of silver; for a woman it is about ·four ounces [ten shekels] of silver.

8.verse: “‘If anyone is too poor to pay the ·price [equivalent], bring him to the priest, and the priest will set the price. The priest will decide how much money the person making the vow can afford to pay.

9.verse: Gifts to the Lord - “‘Some animals may be used as ·sacrifices [gifts] to the LORD. If someone ·promises to bring [gives] one of these to the LORD, it will become holy.

10.verse: That person must not try to ·put another animal in its place [substitute for it] or exchange it, a good animal for a bad one, or a bad animal for a good one. If this happens, both animals will become holy.

11.verse: “‘Unclean [in a ritual sense] animals cannot be offered as ·sacrifices [gifts] to the LORD, and if someone brings one of them to the LORD, that animal must be brought to the priest.

12.verse: The priest will decide a ·price [equivalent] for the animal, according to whether it is good or bad; as the priest decides, that is the ·price [equivalent] for the animal.

13.verse: If the person wants to ·buy back [redeem] the animal, an additional one-fifth must be added to the ·price [equivalent].

14.verse: Value of a House - “‘If a person ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] a house as holy to the LORD, the priest must decide its ·value [equivalent], according to whether the house is good or bad; as the priest decides, that is the ·price [equivalent] for the house.

15.verse: But if the person who ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] the house wants to ·buy it back [redeem it], an additional one-fifth must be added to the ·price [equivalent]. Then the house will belong to that person again.

16.verse: Value of Land - “‘If a person ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] some family property to the LORD, the ·value [equivalent] of the fields will depend on how much seed is needed to plant them. It will cost about ·one and one-fourth pounds [fifty shekels] of silver for each ·six bushels [homer] of barley seed needed.

17.verse: If the person ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] a field at the year of Jubilee [25:8–22], its value [equivalent] ·will stay at what the priest has decided [will stand].

18.verse: But if the person ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] the field after the Jubilee, the priest must ·decide [calculate] the exact ·price [equivalent] by counting the number of years to the next year of Jubilee. Then he will subtract that number from its ·value [equivalent].

19.verse: If the person who ·gave [dedicated; consecrated] the field wants to ·buy it back [redeem it], one-fifth must be added to that ·price [equivalent], and the field will belong to the first owner again.

20.verse: “‘If the person does not ·buy back [redeem] the field, or if it is sold to someone else, the first person cannot ever ·buy it back [redeem it].

21.verse: When the land is released at the year of Jubilee, it will become holy to the LORD, like land ·specially given [devoted] to him. It will become the property of the priests.

22.verse: “‘If someone ·gives [dedicates; consecrates] to the LORD a field he has bought, which is not a part of his family land,

23.verse: the priest must ·count [calculate] the years to the next Jubilee. He must decide the ·price [equivalent] for the land, and the ·price [equivalent] must be paid on that day. Then that land will be holy to the LORD.

24.verse: At the year of Jubilee, the land will go back to its first owner, to the family who sold the land.

25.verse: “‘You must use the measure as set by the ·Holy Place [sanctuary] in paying these ·prices [equivalents]; ·it weighs two-fifths of an ounce [twenty gerahs will make a shekel].

26.verse: Value of Animals - “‘If an animal is the first one born to its parent, it already belongs to the LORD, so people may not ·give [dedicate; consecrate] it again. If it is a ·cow [ox] or a sheep, it is the LORD’s.

27.verse: If the animal is unclean [in a ritual sense], the person must ·buy it back [ransom it] for the ·price set by the priest [equivalent], and the person must add one-fifth to that price. If it is not ·bought back [redeemed], the priest must sell it for ·the price he had decided [its equivalent].

28.verse: “‘·There is a special kind of gift that people set apart to give [All devoted things that are devoted…] to the LORD; it may be a person, animal, or field from the family property. That gift cannot be ·bought back [redeemed] or sold. Every ·special kind of gift [devoted thing] is most holy to the LORD.

29.verse: “‘·If anyone is given for the purpose of being destroyed, he [Everyone who is devoted from among people] cannot be ·bought back [redeemed]; he must be put to death.

30.verse: “‘One-tenth of all crops belongs to the LORD, including the crops from fields and the fruit from trees. That one-tenth is holy to the LORD.

31.verse: If a person wants to ·get back [redeem] that tenth, one-fifth must be added to its price.

32.verse: “‘·The priest will take every [Every] tenth animal from a person’s herd or flock, ·and it [a tenth of all that passes under the shepherd’s rod,] will be holy to the LORD.

33.verse: The owner should not ·pick out the good animals from the bad [inquire whether they are good or bad] or exchange one animal for another. If that happens, both animals will become holy; they cannot be ·bought back [redeemed].’”

34.verse: These are the commands the LORD ·gave to [commanded] Moses at Mount Sinai for the ·people [sons; children] of Israel.
